title: Between 7 February 2020 and 30 June 2020, will a lethal confrontation in Libya result in eight or more fatalities for Turkish armed forces?
preds: very little chance of an event happening between now and the end of the time period.
Heading for the exit, less than a week to go.
If this question comes out with a EOY group I'll be about 65%. The Egyptians have announced their intent to control eastern Libya if Turkey takes Sirte or even moves on it.

This is an odd question. I am sticking at 100% because I have seen news accounts over the 8 casualties between those dates. https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2020-02-23/eastern-libya-forces-say-16-turkish-soldiers-killed-in-fighting
Updated due to the current operational tempo of Turkish forces.

Dropping slightly due to further ongoing talks between Russia & Turkey, as well as continued on-the-ground talks in Libya [1]. Turkey is less likely to send more of their own people in if there is something coming down the pipeline. Tweaking down a bit. Area is pretty busy just not seeing a lot of Turkish activity that would lead me to believe there will be a lethal confrontation withing the time frame.

While only 2 soldiers have been confirmed by Turkey so far, a likelihood of 5% that a single mortality occurs in a day, with 16 days remaining, would imply about 2.8 total deaths, including the 2 already confirmed.

Domestic issues in Turkey (exchange rate of currency TRY towards USD and EUR, NATO-Turkey dissonance, deep recession in tourism and dependence of Turkish trade balance of European tourists,...) outweigh Erdogan strive for expansion of influence. It's become rather a question of survival for the current Turkish regime and their family-friendly and bakshish generating concentration of power.
With Moscow continuing to harass Turkish-backed rebels in Syria, it's not out of the realm of possibility that an "accident" will occur...
Turkey will try to exploit the global occupation with COVID
If more Turkish troops are committed I might go other way but admit the advisors only makes this unlikely.

The possibility of a ceasefire remains, despite Turkey's lack of willingness to take part in any deal which protects Haftar. While it is more likely that the international pressure will continue to limit the extent to which Turkey is directly involved in actions on the ground, I would not rule out the possibility of Turkey attempting a drastic action to kill/remove Khalifa Haftar. If Turkey's force size increases then there is a greater likelihood of a lethal confrontation.

There is ongoing conversation about seizing cities at the same time there are multiple sets of talks going on to end the war [1]. HT to @fisherdbus on the article regarding a possible bus full of Turkish and Syrian troops being hit by Haftar's forces [2]. It seems possible things could either go back-and-forth between talks and fighting for a while or could escalate quickly. Dropping my estimate, as it seems it will be more the former than an escalation including anything beyond a few advisors from Turkey. In this article it said Hafter’s LNA destroyed a bus load of Turkish troops. No confirmation from Turkey or MSM.

We might see Egypts #military intervention.
Raising some. It could be a bluff. Greece supports Hafter and some harsh words between Greece and Turkey too. Raising some. Note: Turkey not yet committing a lot of its own troops yet.

Also, the consensus is  that like 95% that there will be no war, and it's trending down. I'd trust the crowd on this political matter because if there's consensus on all sides it's a consensus of peace.
Reducing my forecast to better match the perception of the risk.
LNA has accepted defeat in Tripoli. I still don't know where the real Turks are positioned, but it seems the heightened danger has passed. And we're already in June...
Reliable reports regarding losses seem sporadic at best. Turkey has also appeared to be employing more PMCs in the conflict.

Adjusting up again based on a review of the news (which I failed to do in-depth enough the first time). But not by much. It seems like most Turkish-supported forces in Libya are not, in fact, Turkish. My read of the question is that casualties among Syrian mercenaries, for example, would not count.

My forecast is low given the impending deadline and the absence of Turkish fatalities to date. However, with recent intensification (LNA announcement to target Turkish sites and Russian aircraft in theatre) there seems to be not an insignificant chance 8 ore more Turkish fatalities.

I'm trying this another way. ACLED lists eight incidents involving Turkish troops in Libya since the beginning of their engagement there, none of which have resulted in a confirmed Turkish fatality. First I try to estimate the true probability of a lethal incident involving Turkish armed forces with the modified Wald method. That's (0+2)/(8+4) = 16%, ± 0.20, so a 95% CI that the true proportion is between 0 and 36%. This is interesting because according to ACLED, just around 16% of confrontations involving Turkish troops in Syria have involved a fatality on any side. The mean number of fatalities for lethal incidents in Syria is 5. Unfortunately, ACLED doesn't tell us which side the fatalities are on, but let's make a simplifying (if unrealistic) assumption of parity; 18% of all fatal incidents involving Turkish troops in Syria involve more than 8 fatalities. So the probability that there will be a fatal incident resulting in at least 8 casualties is then 16% * 18%... so closer to 2%. This degree of calculation is really unwarranted, but I will lower my initial estimate on its basis.

The Turkish military has been active in Libya since February with no confirmed casualties. The Turks seem to be relying heavily on air power. They have a consideragly more developed military and superior weaponry; the LNA, although it seems to have acquired modern jet fighters, has not demonstrated a capability to use them effectively in combat. All it takes is one lucky shot, e.g. to down a Turkish helicopter... but it's not clear that Turkish and Libyan forces are coming into enough direct contact for this luck to take effect.
Good point about Turkey hiding any troop deaths. I will wait a week and if no action lower.
Hafter stayed true to form and is now in consolidation mode BUT lost his two migs, so his ability to hit Turks in FOrce Protection mode is made more difficult.
Note: I will adjust back down if no big battle happens within next week. Good points Balzac!

Why reveal new war planes? You'd normally reveal how and by what means as a *deterrent*.  Recently Egypt and the UAE said Hafter was on his way out. Is this announcement a move by Hafter to demonstrate his power to his supporters, not the GNA? Seems logical. If so, if this is big talk for the sake of Egypt, is this more likely to be a bluff than otherwise? Thinking maybe he's revealing the warplanes to say to Egypt and the UAE "look what I can get? Could a replacement for me acquire these warplanes?"  Just trying to think this through without really understanding much.

Base line: Average lethal fatalities per month in Libya + average number of fatalities for Turkish armed forces in Libia. approx 42 people from armed forces were killed 2017 according to National Commission for Human Rights in Libya (NCHRL). There were 34 recorded attacks so maybe a handful of armed forces killed per time. I am going to assume that the Turkish army is relatively sophisticated so more than 8 fatalities seems above average. Hard to find a good average so my confidence in this number is low. --> 30% Erdogan will not want fatalities and is not seeking confrontation he says. I dont know his true motive but this seems likely. --> 25% Libyan factions will want confrontation. I assume medium but I have little knowledge and confidence. --> 25%
I find this to be a good analysis of the current situation.

Change (-2) Downgrading as the deadline approaches. Opportunities still exist for a clash, the LNA has said that a Turkish base is not off-limits: https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/libyan-army-says-main-turkish-military-base-is-legitimate-target/.

Change (-7) Tensions remain high and an LNA spokesman recently said the LNA was open to attacking a Turkish base (https://www.almasdarnews.com/article/libyan-army-says-main-turkish-military-base-is-legitimate-target/). However without clear scoring criteria and knowing that each side is going to exaggerate the fatality totals one way I am defaulting to downgrading as the window for a confrontation closes.

How is this going to be verified? There are all sorts of reports with conflicting information on how many Turkish soldiers have been killed from 2-16. Assuming it's not going on the LNA's word and it's only 4 currently I'd say there's a very low chance.

I need a clearer standard for determining if this has happened or not by June 30th.  There is a lot of ambiguity in this forecast. Partly because there is no set standard in determining if it has happened or not. Libya is a hotbed for misinformation and both Turkey and the LNA are under incentives to misreport fatality information. On February 25th there was a confrontation in Misrata where Turkish armed forces were involved. However, Erdogan admitted to 2 deaths whereas General Hftar bragged about 16. This incident demonstrates how future confrontations will likely play out: Erdogan wants the fatalities under-reported so that the Turkish public supports his foreign adventurism whereas Hftar wants them over-reported to galvanize his troops. The existence of Syrian mercenaries brought over by Turkey complicates this because some fatalities might not actually be Turkish (but are they still fighting with "the Turkish armed forces"?).  If I were to forecast alone on the probability that this would actually happen with the assumption of accurate reporting I would probably be between 55-60% since there is a good chance it has already happened (according to General Hftar at least). However I don't think there will be accurate reporting unless the incident is really dramatic and there are some structural factors keeping it from being dramatic. Most of the fighting is presently south of Tripoli and reports suggest that the Turkish forces are near Misrata. Additionally because of Corona arms and mercenary shipments to Libya have declined. So I'm betting against reporting of an incident but I am not confident.
It is mostly mercenaries fighting for Turkey. LNA said they killed 16 Turkey soldiers in an incident but Turkey has only owned 2. Lowering this closer to crowd median.
It is likely that there will be further incidents and that those incidents will result in a relatively small number of casualties on the Turkish side.
There have already been multiple incidents with multiple Turkish soldiers being killed since February. The latest incident occurring on April 7th.
This occurrence would seem like a major escalation in the conflict.
I think the fatalities are likely to be on the other side.

While these still seem to be distance in the action, and COVID doesn't seem to yet have a clear impact in the civil war, the movement of Turkish forces into harm's way looks possible.

Given the ostensibly offensive composition of Turkish troop deployment as well as the fact that their presence has agitated the Libyan National army, the chance remains high that Turkish casualties will continue to increase, possibly in a sharp manner if either group decides to launch an offensive. Even if this does not happen, events such as the LNA's March 15 attack on the Mitiga Airport in Tripoli, specifically targeting Turkish forces, seem likely to continue and this mount Turkish casualties.

Around February 25, 2020, Turkey confirmed that 2 of its soldiers were killed in Libya.  President Erdogan also stated that Turkey sustained "several casualties" without being specific. On February 23, 2020, the Libyan National Army (LNA) (who are fighting the Turkish army) under the command of Khalifa Haftar said that they had killed 16 Turkish soldiers in fighting. So far, I have not found an official statement or an exact figure confirming the number of fatalities for the Turkish armed forces. For now, it is either 2 or 16. There is enough time left in this question for the number of Turkish casualties to increase to 8 and beyond. Sources:
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-51626743 https://www.reuters.com/article/us-libya-security/eastern-libya-forces-say-16-turkish-soldiers-killed-in-fighting-idUSKCN20H0JX https://ahvalnews.com/turkey-libya/effect-turkish-military-deaths-libya-may-be-limited-arab-news

down 1% on passage of time. NB there is some significant doubt about honest reporting for this question, given that Turkey seems to have acted secretively on previous occasions when troops have died in Libya and there are rumours that 3 more died beyond the reported 2.
Turkey will probably look to conduct an offensive against Haftar before the summer to get the LNA forces out of the parts of Tripoli they control. Eight troops dying is not an especially high number.
Turkey will try to keep its troops out of harm's way.

Based on the 25 February announcement of Turkish soldiers' deaths in Libya, where Turkey announced 2 soldiers killed and General Haftar's forces claimed to have killed 16 soldiers, I believe the likelihood of 8 Turkish military fatalities before the end of this June remains high. I also believe this is likely because of the possibility that Turkish forces may be emboldened to launch a retaliatory attack, in which more of their soldiers may  be killed.

Based on commentary and first review of news. Issues: - ceasefire: likely or not? [1, 2, 3, 4]
- direct participation by Turkish forces [5, 6]
- the Syria situation [7, 8, 9, 10] If it is indeed true that sending Syrians to fight in Libya won't do the deal to hold the GNA in power - and the parties do not agree on a sustained ceasefire, then more Turkish casualties are unavoidable. I assume a lot will also depend on the conflict in Syria. At the moment, there are still a lot of uncertainties. Currently, I believe that there won't be more than eight fatalities in one single instance of lethal confrontation. [1] https://news.un.org/en/story/2020/02/1056642

The question contemplates a single incident leading to 8+ deaths of Turkish armed forces in a window slightly under five months.
Basic position:
1) The number of Turkish troops in Libya is uncertain.  https://www.thedrive.com/the-war-zone/32002/two-turkish-frigates-appear-of-libya-amid-reports-of-troops-and-armor-landing-ashore
2) Suggested deployment of 2,000 troops, not all of whom would be front-line troops, would require a 0.5% loss in a single incident.  That is a higher rate of loss than experienced by forces in Afghanistan (a reasonable comparable) https://www.statista.com/statistics/262894/western-coalition-soldiers-killed-in-afghanistan/. See also figure 5 here https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/789873/20190328_UK_Deaths_National_Statistic_2019_O.pdf  (If the troops deployed are fewer than 2,000 during the period in question then the rate would have to be higher.)
3) The question assumes fatalities - and so there is a danger of conflating the question of how likely it is that there would be a large number of casualties in any one incident with how many of those casualties would die in the incident or subsequently. Modern military medicine and available access to medical facilities either onshore, offshore or in Turkey suggests that even if there was an incident with high casualty numbers the fatality numbers would be low.  https://watermark.silverchair.com/milmed-d-09-00130.pdf  Taken together suggests the answer should be low probability of "yes" However, existing deployment is said to already have led to an incident involving 3 dead and 6 wounded
 https://ahvalnews.com/libya/three-turkish-soldiers-killed-libya-haftars-forces-advance-misrata
(Though these are presumably special forces or recon troops who are more exposed and whose mission will reduce as the deployment increases.) Further factors suggesting caution on the part of Turkish troops:
1) Turkish strategy doesn't appear to favour direct conflict, which would exacerbate regional tensions. Instead it seeks, by the presence of troops, to ensure it has a say any ceasefire and diplomatic discussions.
See https://www.politico.eu/article/road-to-peace-in-libya-goes-through-turkey-khalifa-haftar/ and https://www.dailysabah.com/op-ed/2020/01/13/turkeys-troops-in-libya-whats-their-mission
2) The measure was domestically controversial and direct casualties would exacerbate domestic difficulties.  At the same time, Turkey has proxy units available for direct conflicts if needed. 
https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/turkey-libya-troops-parliament-vote-erdogan-a9267716.html  and https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2020/02/syria-opposition-fighters-deploy-libya-turkey-offer.html The basic position dominates and is reinforced by Turkish strategic considerations - 5%

https://ahvalnews.com/libya/three-turkish-soldiers-killed-libya-haftars-forces-advance-misrata - 3 died in January "Estimates from diplomats in Turkey about the number of Syrian fighters vary from 1,500 to 3,000, while the number of Turkish troops was seen at between 200 to 500 including special forces, conventional troops and drone operators." - from https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/analysis-libyas-rival-factions-dig-in-for-long-conflict-2020-02-17 The size of the force isn't huge and we have to remember this asks about 8 or more dying in a single combat incident.
Most of the fighting will be done by proxy forces with Turkish troupes focused on training and covert operations.

Because the warring sides and their sponsors are rivaled against each other in other parts of the world as well, the current equation in Libya is not independent of the directions of the rivalries in those regions. Situations in East Mediterranean, Syria and Ukraine are the main stages that determine the future of Libyan conflict. Some of the dynamics driving the level of tensions in these three stages are mainly political, diplomatic and economic. We know Haftar is well supported by Russia because Russia needs to have control over the supply of oil (due to sanctions). Kremlin related Wagner troops have been fighting for Haftar. On the other hand Turkey had no choice but to support Sarraj because Greek and Cypriot EEZ advancements threatened its sovereign rights over its continental shelf. So, it sought sea neighbors to back its EEZ claims to cancel Greek EEZ claims. 
Russia also backs Assad in Syria. Turkey is against Assad. In Syria, Russia and Turkey are disputing over Idlib province. Because of this dispute a military confrontation began lately and resulted with TSK casualties. Although Russia's aim toward Idlib is more complex (securing Iran's Latakia settlement to relieve pressure on Russian military settlements in Tartus) than it seems, it directed SAA to use more lethal force than usual on Turkish positions in the most recent counteroffensives. The reason for that was Russia's loss of 4 FSB special operations agents during Turkish led offensive toward Aleppo. So, that makes TSK casualties are result of a Russian retaliation. This means the risk of heightened conflict in Idlib may actually be lower than expected. 
However, the exchange of attacks led Turkey to take political steps in Ukraine. Turkey expressed support for Kiev and stated that it would not recognize Crimea as Russian territory. Turkey also beefed up its observation points in Idlib. Ankara stated that Syrian army and whoever are with them would be hit hard unless Syrian army retreat back to the line agreed in Sochi. Russian sponsored Haftar had left negotiations after Turkey insisted on conditions of ceasefire which Moscow also had disagreed in some terms. This shows Haftar does what Kremlin tells him to do. 
There have been Turkish attacks in Libya against Haftar positions. Russian drones were downed outside Tripoli by Turkey backed groups, again in retaliation of similar Haftar offensives. Turkey deployed some radical proxies from idlib to Tripoli and sent armed vehicles and tanks. Such steps were to pose deterrence for Kremlin, which has been fighting in many other theaters in various different regions. Despite all these developments, we have not yet seen a serious all-out offensive has been taken against Turkish positions by Haftar. One of the most important reasons for that is Kremlin's understanding that Turkish soldiers are protecting and supporting a UN recognized government in Libya, and that any attack on Turkish troops would risk Haftar's legitimacy, therefore would undermine Russia's gains in Libya. 
Turkey is using its own troops mainly for conducting training, arming and consulting missions for Sarraj army in Libya. In turn, its military existence is much smaller in size compared to Idlib. This is also a factor lowering the possibility of casualties from Turkish side.
However, if, by the end of this month Assad forces do not retreat back to the line Ankara has mentioned, there is a likelihood that a Turkish offensive in response may cause some Russian casualties on Syrian side, an answer to which may be coupled by Haftar's heavy artillery to Tripoli, resulting Turkish casualties.
So there's still a possibility of a lethal confrontation that may result in 8 or more deaths from TSK side in Libya.The main determinant for that likelihood will be Syrian army's position at the end of this month (Feb 2020) and the Turkish response to that. US support for Turkish offensive, as well as Turkey's geographical advantage may deter Russia which may result with Assad's retreat back to Sochi line.  I believe the likelihood of a lethal conflict causing deaths of Turkish troops in Libya will remain low within the next 5 months because diplomatic relations between Kremlin and Ankara aren't damaged as severe for Russia to order an attack on UN recognized government's positions which most of the Turkish troops are located at.

Thus far Haftar has defied Moscow and pressed his attack forward increasing the probability of a confrontation (Haftar likely sees Turkey as the main guarantor of the GNA, and thus is an attractive target).  The Turks - with a economic and ideological interest - are attempting to do just enough to prevent Haftar's advance while maintaining a small, defensible footprint.  The Turks will likely attempt to avoid direct confrontation between Turkish forces and opposition forces, but their adversaries (particularly the LNA) will likely see a strike on Turkish forces that results in casualties a way to hinder Turkish public support for the operation and possibly force a withdrawal.  Eight casualties isn't especially high (a car bomb or well-placed airstrike could cause that).  When we say Turkish Armed Forces, does that count proxies?  My probability would increase if it does.  Without knowing exact Turkish troop numbers in Libya, it is hard to be precise.
With tensions high, U.S. troops largely out of harm's way, and a disinterested U.S. president, the likelihood of a significant lethal contribution seems high.

Given the report of casualties in January (3 Turkish soldiers killed and 6 injured) and the increase in conventional force deployment (https://www.thedrive.com/the-war-zone/32002/two-turkish-frigates-appear-of-libya-amid-reports-of-troops-and-armor-landing-ashore), in which 2 Turkish frigates are reported to have offloaded troops and armor onto the coast of Tripoli; I believe it is highly likely that the increase in Turkish presence and likely increase in aggressive posture will lead to an increase in combat casualties. I believe that the deployment of armored assets indicates that Turkey is preparing for offensive operations, which will certainly lead to casualties, given the amount of territory and apparent close air support capability held by General Haftar's forces.

With recent deaths in Syria and under domestic political pressure, it is unlikely that Erdogan will attempt to move Turkish troops into an aggressive posture in Libya, therefore reducing the likelihood of casualties (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-51447114). According to Erdogan, Turkey has only sent 35 advisors, however, this should not be taken for granted as Turkish special forces are also likely operating in AO (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/jan/13/turbulence-for-turkey-as-breakaway-parties-make-gains-on-erdogan).  Just five days after the deployment, 3 Turkish soldiers were allegedly killed and another 6 were wounded when a rebel aircraft backed by the UAE bombed their position (https://ahvalnews.com/libya/three-turkish-soldiers-killed-libya-haftars-forces-advance-misrata). With modern weapons and warplanes, Libyan rebel groups have the capabilities to pose a threat to Turkish advisors even behind the frontlines (https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/nation-world/story/2020-01-04/death-toll-from-airstrike-in-libyas-tripoli-climbs-to-30).  With Turkish backed Syrian fighters in the region, I predict more violence but I am hesitant to argue that uniformed Turkish forces will be present.

According to the Turkish government, there are currently 35 military advisors in Libya. (1)* It would be reasonable to suspect that this is not the whole truth, and there would be special forces or some other elements active in the country. There are reports that Syrian mercenaries in Libya being paid for by the Turkish government, so it would not be unreasonable think that the Turkish armed forces are there to co-ordinate the mercenaries that they are employing. For this question to resolve as yes, the main thing that would be an increase in the number of Turkish soldiers in the country.  If they were to increase the military presence, the this would become more likely to resolve as yes simply because the numbers would become more viable. This would not resolve as yes if there were a helicopter accident resulting in 8 deaths, but if a helicopter was shot down by opposition forces and it contained 8 Turkish soldiers it would. I will update as I find more information about the troop numbers of Turkish soldiers. I am also assuming this question is asking about 8 casualties total and not in one incident.  Interestingly there were 8 casualties in the first 6 months or so in the Russian intervention which began in 2015.
